Report and Recommendation of the President  
to the Board of Directors 
 

Sri Lanka 
Project Number: 45094-003 
October 2014 
 
 

Proposed Loan for Additional Financing  
Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste: Road Network 
Upgrading Project 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Distribution of this document is restricted until it has been approved by  the Board of Directors. 
Following such approval, ADB will disclose the document to the public in accordance with ADB's 
Public Communications Policy 2011.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Democratic  Republic  of  Timor-Leste  for  the  additional  financing  of  the  Road  Network 
Upgrading Project.  
 
2. 
The  proposed  additional  financing  will  support  a  change  in  the  scope  of  the  Road 
Network  Upgrading  Project. The Government  of  Timor-Leste will  construct  a new  international 
port at Tibar west of Dili, which is currently served by a road included in the scope of the original 
project.  To  provide  sufficient  capacity,  5.0  kilometers  (km)  of  the  road  will  be  designed  and 
constructed to a significantly higher standard than originally envisaged. The additional financing 
will also help finance cost overruns in the original project arising from civil works costs that were 
higher than expected. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
In  2011,  the  government  published  its  strategic  development  plan  (SDP),  2011–2030, 
which  aims  to  sustain  economic  growth  and  fast-track  economic  development  to  achieve  a 
modern  and  diversified  economy  with  high-quality  infrastructure. 1 The  SDP  envisages  three 
pillars  for  development:  social  capital  development,  infrastructure  development,  and  economic 
development. Public investment (including roads) over the first 5 years of the SDP is intended to 
create  the  conditions  to  attract  private  investment  and  ensure  that  the  economy  is  led  by  the 
private sector by 2030. An efficient and safe transport system is essential to achieving the three 
developmental  pillars.  The  SDP  and  the  operational  plans  of  the  government  emphasize  the 
upgrading of roads. 
 
Since 1999, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been the lead development agency 
4. 
in the road subsector, for which it has provided six technical assistance projects, three project 
grants, one sector grant, and two loans. The country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 continues 
ADB’s  strategic  directions  by  concentrating  on  infrastructure  development  and  management. 
ADB plans to provide complementary assistance in the core specializations of finance, regional 
cooperation and integration, and education. 2 ADB will also support the private sector as a key 
driver  of  change  to  help  make  the  transition  from  an  economy  led  by  the  public  sector.3 ADB 
support  for  infrastructure,  financial  services,  and  skills  training  will  help  meet  the  needs  of  a 
growing  economy.  An  emphasis  on  the  provision  of  services  outside  the  capital  will  support 
growth of the rural economy. Poverty will be reduced, particularly in rural areas, by connecting 
the poor to markets and expanding the availability of basic public services.  
 
The original project was approved in March 2012, and became effective in June 2012. 4 
5. 
The  original  project  intended  to  (i)  reconstruct  or  upgrade  and  climate  proof  about  59  km  of 
principal  national  roads,  (ii)  expand  the  road  maintenance  program  of  the  Ministry  of  Public 
Works  (MPW),  and  (iii)  complete  a  feasibility  study  and  detailed  design  for  81  km  of  principal 

                                                
1   Government of Timor-Leste. 2011. Timor-Leste Strategic Development Plan, 2011–2030. Dili. 
2  ADB. 2011. Country Partnership Strategy: Timor-Leste, 2011–2015. Manila. 
3  The  country  partnership  strategy  addresses  four  of  ADB’s  five  core  specializations,  as  identified  in  ADB.  2008. 

Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. Manila. 

4   ADB.  2012.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Loan  to  the 

Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for the Road Network Upgrading Project. Manila. 

 

 2 

 

national roads. The executing agency is the Council for the Administration of the Infrastructure 
Fund (CAFI) through its Major Projects Secretariat, and the implementing agency is the MPW. 5 
 
6. 
The  original  project  includes  a  component  for  upgrading  the  existing  road  between  Dili 
and  Liquica.  This  responded  directly  to  the  SDP  which  envisages  completion  of  this  28  km 
section by 2015. The road is part of the north coast road linking Dili with the Indonesian border 
at Mota Ain and with the western towns of Maliana and Bobonaro. The component is intended 
to facilitate  increased  and  more  efficient  movement  of people and goods  between the  districts 
and the capital as well as cross-border trade with Indonesia. 
 
7. 
The  government  has  confirmed  its  intention  to  relocate  the  international  port  in  Dili  to 
Tibar  with  operations  envisaged  to  commence  by  2018.  Tibar  is  situated  on  the  Dili–Liquica 
road,  the  upgrading  of  which  is  included  in  the  project.  There  has  been  substantial  growth  in 
freight  volumes  through  Dili  port  and  it  is  expected  to  reach  its  capacity  by  2015.  Accelerated 
construction and operation of a new port under a public–private partnership is now planned. The 
current  project  scope  includes  only  rehabilitation  between  Dili  and  Tibar  following  the  existing 
road.  However,  the  winding  alignment,  coastal  exposure,  and  areas  of  hillside  instability  will 
become  a  constraint  on  future  upgrading,  which  will  be  required  in  light  of  the  planned  port 
development. 
 
A reassessment of the scope of the original component has been undertaken. In addition 
8. 
to the traffic  now  expected  to  be generated  by the  port  development,  the reassessment found 
that  there  had  been  higher-than-expected  growth  in  the  base  traffic,  averaging  19%  per  year 
since  2009.  This  growth  is  attributable  to  population  growth  in  the  immediate  area  of  8%  per 
annum  and  development  of  business  (particularly  warehousing)  in  Tibar.  The  reassessment 
found  that  a  road  of  significantly  higher  geometric  standard  than  that  currently  included  in  the 
project  scope  is  required.  A  dual  carriageway,  5.0  km  long  (partly  on  a  new  alignment),  has 
been  found  to  be  feasible  as  a  long-term  solution.  It  will  improve  the  alignment  and  avoid  the 
coastal and unstable areas. It will also shorten the distance between Dili and the new port by 2 
km  (see  map).  The  construction  cost  is  estimated  to  be  significantly  higher  than  the  cost  of 
construction of the originally envisaged scope. However, economic and financial analysis shows 
the  changed  project  to  be  viable,  with  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  27.3%.  The 
government  has  requested  additional  financing  to  finance  additional  costs  arising  from  the 
changed scope as the proposed changes can readily be implemented under the existing project 
arrangements. 
 
In  addition,  bids  received  for  civil  works  under  the  original  project  were  approximately 
9. 
30%  higher  than  anticipated  and  the  additional  cost  cannot  be  fully  met  by  the  contingency 
amount  included  in  the  original  financing  plan.  The  components  continue  to  be  economically 
viable  and  are  high government  priorities.  The  government  has  therefore  requested  additional 
financing to also help finance this cost overrun. 
 
10. 
Regarding the performance of the project to date, procurement of civil works (output 1) 
has  suffered  delay  because  of  capacity  constraints  in  the  National  Procurement  Commission 
(NPC),  which  is  responsible  for  managing  all  major  public  procurement.  A  newly  established 
body with responsibility for final endorsement of government contracts (the Audit Court) caused 
delays  in  meeting  contractual  conditions  precedent  to  commencement  of  work.  Progress  on 
output  1  was  14  months  behind  schedule  by  the  time  construction  commenced  in  November 
2013.  Disbursement  performance  in  2013  was  therefore  significantly  affected  and  behind  the 
original projections ($4.7 million versus $17.0 million projected as of February 2014). Revisions 

                                                
5   The MPW is the successor to the Ministry of Infrastructure. 

 

 to  the  disbursement  forecast  have  been  made  based  on  the  status  of  disbursements  in 
February  2014,  and  disbursements  since  then  have  been  satisfactory.  However,  the  original 
project  is  considered  to  be  not  performing  well  because  the  original  disbursement  projections 
were  not  met  in the  12-month  period  preceding cross-departmental  review  of this  proposal for 
additional financing.6 
 
  
11. 
A  contract  for  the  supervision  of  construction  of  the  two  roads  and  for  the  design  of  a 
further  81 km  of  road  was  procured  and  awarded  without  significant  delay  by  December  2012 
and  work  commenced  in  January  2013.  The  consulting  firm  has  performed  satisfactorily  and 
completed  the  required  feasibility  study  and  detailed  engineering  design  (output  2)  by  August 
2013. This has supported processing of subsequent ADB loans.7  
 
The  delays  may  be  ascribed  to  a  learning  period  within  the  various  government 
12. 
agencies,  as  new  processes  are  bedded  into  government  systems  and  capacity  to  use  the 
systems effectively is improved. Recent experience is that the NPC is competent and is steadily 
reducing  the  time  required  to  conduct  bid  processes. 8  The  Audit  Court  must  now  review 
government  contracts  within  30  days.  Works  contracts  under  the  original  project  are  now 
proceeding satisfactorily and are expected to be completed by end of 2015. There is no current 
impediment  to  achieving  the  project  outputs.  Successful  completion  of  civil  works  is  the  key 
factor  in  achieving  the  project  outcome.  Compliance  with  safeguards  is  satisfactory.  Project 
performance  and  associated  issues  are  described  in  more  detail  in  the  summary  of  project 
performance.9 
 
The  changed  project  meets  all  eligibility  criteria  for  additional  financing.10 The  project 
13. 
remains  technically  feasible,  economically  viable,  and  financially  sound  and  infrastructure 
development, including upgrading of roads and construction of a new port, are high government 
priorities.  The  changed  project  remains  consistent  with  the  development  objectives  of  the 
original  project  and  is  consistent  with  the  current  country  partnership  strategy.  The  existing 
project implementation arrangements remain satisfactory (though some additional resources are 
required)  and  an  extension  of  the  existing  loans  of  only  1  year  is  needed  to  accommodate 
accrued delays and the changed scope of work. All components are being executed within the 
same geographical area, therefore arrangements for construction supervision can be extended 
to the changed project. The safeguards categorization of the project is unchanged.  
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

The impact of the project will be increased and more efficient movement of people and 
14. 
goods. The outcome will be that the MPW provides a more reliable and safer road network. The 
impact  and  outcome  are  unchanged  by  the  changed  output.  New  performance  targets  for  the 
changed  output  (the road  section  connecting  Dili  to the  new  international  port)  are included  in 
the revised design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1).  
 

                                                
6   ADB. 2011. Operational Procedures. Operations Manual. OMH5/OP. Manila (para. 39 [ii]). 
7   ADB.  2013.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President:  Road  Network  Upgrading  Sector  Project.  Manila 

(approved for $50.0 million on 19 September 2013). 

8   The NPC has satisfactorily conducted procurement of two major civil works contracts and two consultant service 

contracts under the Road Network Upgrading Sector Project in 2014. 

9   Summary of Project Performance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).  
10  ADB. 2011. Bank Policies. Operations Manual. OMH5/BP. Manila (para. 4). 

 

3 

 

 4 

 

C. 

Outputs 

Five  key  outputs  will  contribute  towards  achieving  the  project  outcome  and  impact.  All 

15. 
outputs with the exception of output 1 are unchanged: 

(i)  Output 1: National roads will be upgraded and climate proofed. Upgrading of 
the roads from Dili to Liquica (28.6 km) and Tibar to Gleno (31.0 km) are original 
components  of  Output  1.  The  Dili  to  Liquica  components  will  be  changed  from 
upgrading of the road from Dili airport road junction to Liquica to upgrading of the 
road from Tacitolu to Liquica. The changed component will therefore comprise: (i) 
realignment  and  upgrading  to  four  lanes  from  Taciltolu  to  the  junction  with  the 
Tibar  to  Gleno  road  including  construction  of  a  roundabout  at  this  junction  (3.2 
km),  (ii)  upgrading  to  four  lanes  from  the  roundabout  to  Tibar  Port  entrance  (2 
km)  including  provision  for  port  access  and  (iii)  widening  to  6  meters  (m)  and 
strengthening  of  the  road  from  Tibar  Port  entrance  to  Liquica  (19.1  km).  The 
Tibar  to  Gleno  component  which  commences  at  the  junction  with  the  above 
component  will  be  unchanged  from  its  present  strengthening  and  widening 
existing sealed pavements from a width of generally less than 4.5 m to 6 m with 
asphalt surfacing. Vulnerability to damage from severe rainfall, sea level rise, and 
other  potential  effects  of  climate  change  for  all  roads  will  be  reduced  through 
engineering  counter-measures, 
including  ensuring  suitably-sized  drainage 
structures,  raising  of  road  levels  that  are  flood-prone,  and  bio-engineering  to 
promote slope stability. 
Output  2:  A  feasibility  study  and  detailed  design  will  be  prepared.  A 
feasibility  study  and  detailed  design  suitable for  ADB  financing  will  be  prepared 
for the road from Manatuto to Natarbora (81.0 km). The additional loan will help 
finance  the  detailed  design  of  the  road  from  Comoro  roundabout  to  Tibar  Port 
entrance. 
Output 3: Performance-based road maintenance will be introduced. The civil 
works  contractors  will  be  responsible  for  maintenance  of  the  upgraded  road 
sections for 2 years after physical completion. Local contractors will be trained in 
performance maintenance, and period performance-based contracts will be used 
for future maintenance. 
Output 4: Awareness of road safety and transport-related social issues will 
be  raised.  The  awareness  of  road  safety  will  be  increased  by  implementing  a 
community-based  road  safety  awareness  program,  including  an  education 
program for schools, drivers, road users, and the community, and implementing 
an HIV/AIDS prevention and a human trafficking awareness program. 
Output  5:  Efficient  project  management  will  be  provided.  The  project 
includes  project  management  support  for  the  implementing  agency  through 
strengthening of its project management unit (PMU). 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv)

D. 
 
16. 
The  total  cost  of  the  project  after  additional  financing  is  estimated  to  be  $79.88  million 
(Table  1). 11 Collaborative  cofinancing  from  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  for 
$93.0 million is excluded from Tables 1 and 2 for clarity.12  

                                                
11 The additional financing will be for the upgrading and construction supervision of the road from  Tasitolu to Tibar, 
cost overruns for the Tibar to Liquica and Tibar to Gleno components, and strengthening the capacity of the PMU 
and government agencies for land acquisition and resettlement. 

12  The  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  has  provided  a  loan  to  the  Government  of  Timor-Leste  for  the 
upgrading  of  the  road  from  Dili  to  Baucau,  and  this  was  included  as  collaborative  financing  in  the  original.  The

d  Physical contingencies computed at  5% for already contracted civil works; 10% for additional (uncontracted) civil 
works; and 10% for field research and development, training, surveys, and studies. Price contingencies computed 
at 3.3% on foreign exchange costs and 18.1% on local currency costs. 

e  Includes interest and commitment charges. Interest during construction for ADB loan(s) has been computed at the

charges for an ADB loan are 0.15% per year to be charged on the undisbursed loan amount.  

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
The  government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $11.78  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
17. 
resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term (straight line repayment 
method), including a grace period of 5 years, an annual interest rate determined in accordance 
with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge 
of  0.15%  per  year  (the  interest  and  other  charges  during  construction  to  be  capitalized  in  the 
loan), and such other terms and conditions set forth in the  loan agreement. Based on this, the 
average  loan  maturity  is  15.25  years  and  the  maturity  premium  payable  to  ADB  is  0.1%  per 
annum. The loan from ADB will finance civil works, consultants’ services, taxes and duties, late 
payment  charges  imposed  by  suppliers  and  contractors,  bank  charges,  and  interest  during 
construction on the ordinary capital resources loan.13 The government has provided ADB with (i) 
the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based on these 
terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii)  an  undertaking  that  these  choices  were  its  own  independent 
decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
18. 
financing shortfall to ensure project outputs are fully implemented.  

The financing plan is in Table 2. The government has assured ADB that it will meet any 

 

 
                                                                                                                                                       
agency’s part of the project is proceeding satisfactorily, with invitations for bids for civil works issued in the second 
quarter of 2014. 

13 Financing  of  late  payment  charges  and  bank  charges  will  avoid  potential  administrative  delays.  The  amount  of 
taxes and duties (i) is within the reasonable threshold identified during the country partnership strategy preparation 
process, (ii) does not represent an excessive share of the project investment plan, and (iii) will only be financed in 
respect of ADB-financed expenditures. Financing of taxes and duties is material and relevant to the success of the 
project.

19. 
An  existing  PMU  within  the  MPW  is  responsible  for  the  management  of  the  original 
project  and  will  also manage the  changed  outputs. The  PMU  is  headed  by  a project  manager 
and staffed with key professionals on a full-time basis, including a chief technical advisor, road 
construction  advisor,  road  maintenance  engineer,  and  financial  administrator.  Supplementary 
staff have been recruited to the PMU and financed under the original project, and also under the 
ADB-financed Road Network Upgrading Sector Project (footnote 7). The supplementary staff of 
international and national specialists provide for a full-time safeguards unit within the PMU. The 
PMU  will  continue  to  be  responsible  for  financial  management  and  preparing  withdrawal 
applications. The existing Road Network Upgrading Project design and supervision consultant is 
responsible for construction supervision of the Tibar to Liquica and Tibar to Gleno components 
(under its existing contract) and for the additional Tasitolu to Tibar component (under a contract 
variation).  
 
20.  While  the  day-to-day  management  of  the  project  will  be  undertaken  by  the  PMU,  the 
government’s  National  Development  Agency  will  review  quality,  costs,  and  payments  in 
accordance with the government’s internal procedures. While the PMU, assisted by the design 
and  supervision  consultants,  will  prepare  draft  bidding  documents  for  procurement  of  the 
additional component, the NPC will be responsible for conducting the bidding process, including 
bid evaluation. 
 
21. 
Table 3 and described in detail in the project administration manual.14

ADB  =  Asian  Development  Bank,  CAFI  =  Conselho  de  Administração  do  Fundo  Infraestrutura  (Council  for  the 
Administration  of  the  Infrastructure  Fund),  CQS  =  consultant’s  qualifications  selection,  ICS  =  individual  consultant 
selection, LCS = least-cost selection, QCBS = quality- and cost-based selection. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical  

Upgrading  of  roads  will  include  side  slope  stabilization,  drainage  improvement,  and 
22. 
pavement reconstruction and widening. This will involve construction of retaining structures and 
use  of  bioengineering  works  for  slope  stabilization,  improved  drainage,  and  strengthened  and 
widened road pavements. Widening will be carried out only where technically and economically 
feasible in light of challenging geotechnical conditions in some locations. In the changed project, 
the road from Tasitolu to Tibar port entrance will be upgraded to dual carriageway standard to 
increase its capacity. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

23. 
Economic  assessment  of  the  components  has  been  undertaken  utilizing  the  roads 
economic  decision  model,  a  derivative  of  the  highway  development  and  management  model. 

7 

 

 8 

 

The original project was found to have a rate of return of 16%. Sensitivity tests were applied and 
the  economic  internal  rates  of  return  remained  above  10%  under  all  scenarios  analyzed.  The 
changed Liquica to Tibar road was found to have a rate of return of 27.3% and remained above 
12.0%  under  all  sensitivity  scenarios.  Maintaining  the  unimproved  road  to  a  basic  serviceable 
standard  is  estimated  to  cost  $0.25  million  per  year,  compared  with  $0.09  million  per  year  for 
the upgraded road. The government has adequate financial capacity to finance maintenance of 
its infrastructure assets.  

 
Governance 

C. 

24. 
The  public  financial  management  system  is  heavily  centralized  with  numerous  controls 
that  have  resulted  in  bottlenecks  that  slow  payment  processes.  Decentralization  of  noncore 
financial  management  functions  from  the  Ministry  of  Finance  to  line  ministries  has  been 
promoted,  as  capacity  within  these  agencies  has  increased  but  the  system  for  contract 
payments continues to involve a number of agencies. 
 
The NPC was established in 2011 and is responsible for all procurement over $1 million. 
25. 
Its  performance  to  date  has  been  satisfactory,  albeit  slow  because  of  internal  capacity 
constraints.  The  transparency  and  efficiency  of  procurement  still  needs  improvement,  and  a 
balance between risk and accountability for projects without development partner oversight has 
not yet been achieved. 
 
26. 
The  executing  agency,  CAFI,  was  established  in  2011  to  oversee  the  use  of  the 
infrastructure fund.15 The Civil Service Act (2004) provides standards, principles, definitions, and 
guidelines  for  civil  service  administration;  a  code  of  ethics  for  civil  servants;  and  an 
administrative  disciplinary  mechanism.  A  law  creating  the  new  Anti-Corruption  Commission 
became  effective  in  2009,  and  the  first  anticorruption  commissioner  was  appointed  in  2010. 
However,  the  independence  of  this  commission  needs  to  be  assured  and  it  needs  to  be 
resourced effectively. 
 
27. 
The MPW has implemented a number of ADB-supported infrastructure projects through 
its  PMU  since  2010,  including  the  Road  Network  Development  Sector  Project,  the  Road 
Network  Upgrading  Project,  and the  Road Network  Upgrading  Sector  Project.  Its  performance 
with  regard  to  financial  management  has  been  satisfactory,  though  delays  have  been 
experienced  because  of  controls  and  reviews  of  certified  payments  conducted  by  other 
agencies,  including  the  Ministry  of  Finance.  The  PMU  has  sufficient  capacity  to  manage  the 
changed project. 
 
28. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and CAFI. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the project administration manual (footnote 14). 

 
Poverty and Social 

D. 

The  primary  beneficiaries  of  the  original  project  are  (i)  road  users,  including  vehicle 
29. 
drivers  and  passengers  and/or  nonmotorized  transport  users;  (ii)  households  living  in 
communities in the catchment areas of the upgraded road links that sell a range of cash crops 
and  other  agricultural  produce;  (iii)  passenger  and  goods  transport  service  providers  and 
commercial  truck  drivers;  and  (iv)  small  businesses  and  traders  including  vendors  at  local 

                                                
15 The  infrastructure  fund  is  derived  from  the  petroleum-revenue-financed  sovereign  wealth  fund  and  is  used  for 

financing infrastructure development. 

 

 markets,  trade  store  owners,  coffee  and  other  produce  buyers,  and  small  and  medium-sized 
enterprises in the district capitals and towns. The changed project will  also benefit businesses 
engaged  in  import  and  export  of  goods  through  provision  of  a  shorter  and  more  efficient  land 
transport link between the port and Dili. Lower transport costs will contribute to lower prices for 
imported goods, which will benefit all segments of society, especially the poor. 
 
30.  
The  project  is  classified  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming  and  is  designed  to  ensure 
gender equality and allow women’s empowerment by ensuring that the views and requirements 
of  women  are  fully  considered  in  the  design  of  the  components.  Women’s  involvement  in  all 
employment  and  training  opportunities  under  the  changed  project  will  continue  to  be  actively 
promoted.16 Specifically, the project will encourage and facilitate (i) incorporation of the views of 
women in the project design; (ii) awareness of gender and transport security, human trafficking, 
and  HIV/AIDS,  (iii)  a  reasonable  quota  for  women’s  involvement  in  the  construction  work, 
directed  toward  unemployed  widows,  female  heads  of  households  with  large  numbers  of 
dependents,  and  other  vulnerable  groups;  and  (iv)  a  quota  for  women’s  involvement  in 
bioengineering and maintenance works. 

 
Safeguards 

E. 

31. 
Environment.  The  project  is  classified  category  B.  An  environmental  assessment  and 
review  framework  and  initial  environmental  examinations  were  prepared  for  both  original 
components.  An  initial  environmental  examination  has  been  prepared  for  the  changed 
component. The original project’s environmental impacts are site specific and temporary. They 
include  (i)  disturbance  from  dust  arising  from  loading,  unloading,  and  transportation  of 
construction  materials; (ii)  noise;  (iii)  erosion  and  sedimentation from  exposed  surfaces  during 
construction  that  may  affect  water  courses;  (iv)  risks  from  the  use  and  disposal  of  hazardous 
materials such as fuel and lubricants; and (v) increased risk of accidents from increased vehicle 
movements. The new component has more significant but manageable impacts, including loss 
of  vegetation  in  the  area  of  the  new  alignment  and  widening  alongside  200  m  of  coastline. 
Mitigation measures have been incorporated in all components as outlined in the environmental 
management plans. The PMU will implement the environmental management plans and employ 
a full-time national environment specialist and a full-time international specialist in its safeguards 
unit to monitor and report on progress.  
 
32. 
Resettlement.  The  additional  financing  project  is  classified  category  B  on  involuntary 
resettlement.  The  road  widening  under  the  additional  financing  will  impact  private  land  (0.71 
hectares) and assets, including 11 houses, eight kiosks, four fences, and several trees. A total 
of  15  households  (109  persons)  will  be  affected.  A  resettlement  plan  has  been  prepared  in 
accordance  with  the  government-endorsed  resettlement  framework  for  the  Road  Network 
Upgrading  Project  and  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009). 17  The  resettlement  plan 
includes  necessary  measures  on  compensation  and  resettlement  assistance  to  enhance  or 
restore the living standards of affected persons.18 The plan will be updated, and compensation 
and relocation activities completed before the start of civil works on the affected land. The PMU 
will  implement  the  resettlement  plans  and  employ  a full-time  national  specialist  and  a  full-time 
international specialist in its safeguards unit to monitor and report on progress. The project will 
also  strengthen  the  capacity  of  the  PMU  and  government  agencies  on  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement. Additional consultant services will include a resettlement specialist, a legal advisor, 
and a resettlement coordinator. 

                                                
16  Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
17  Resettlement Plan for Tasitolu–Tibar (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
18 The resettlement plan has been posted on the ADB website and disclosed locally to affected persons. 

9 

 

 10 

 

Indigenous  persons.  The  additional  financing  project  is  classified  category  C  for 
33. 
indigenous  peoples.  No  distinct  and  vulnerable  indigenous  peoples  as  defined  under  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement are expected to be affected by the project. 

 
Risks and Mitigating Measures 

F. 

34. 
No  significant  additional  issues  have  arisen  from  the  risks  identified  for  the  original 
project.  Slow  procurement  and  delayed  disbursement  have  affected  project  implementation. 
Procurement  performance  has  improved  (footnote  6)  and  disbursement  will  be  dependent  on 
physical progress which is now satisfactory. Major risks and mitigating measures are described 
in  detail  in  the  risk  assessment  and  risk  management  plan. 19  The  integrated  benefits  and 
impacts are expected to outweigh the costs. 
 

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

The government and CAFI have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 

35. 
The  government  and  CAFI  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  project  shall 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
36. 
which are set forth in the loan agreement.  
 
37. 
The  government  has  agreed  that  no  withdrawals  can  be  made  from  the  loan  account 
subcategory  for  Works  in  respect  of  any  works  from  Tibar  roundabout  to  Gleno  and  Tibar 
roundabout to Liquica until all of the allocated funds for the works and unallocated categories of 
the original loans have been fully disbursed.   
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

38. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$11,780,000 to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for the additional financing of the Road 
Network  Upgrading  Project,  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be 
determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility;  for  a  term  of  25  years, 
including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 

Takehiko Nakao 
President 

 
 
3 October 2014
